intro: Abutilon macranthum, commonly known as the large-flowered abutilon, is a species of flowering plant in the mallow family. It is native to South America, particularly Brazil, and is characterized by its showy, lantern-shaped flowers. The plant has hairy, lobed leaves and can grow as a shrub or small tree, reaching up to 5 meters in height. It thrives in warm, humid climates and is often cultivated for its ornamental value. The flowers, which are typically yellow or orange, bloom in late spring and early summer.
distribution_native_art_desc: Abutilon macranthum is primarily native to Southeast Asia, including countries such as Thailand, Malaysia, Indonesia, and the Philippines. This plant is commonly associated with humid climates and is often seen growing in secondary forests or disturbed areas. It is also present in some parts of southern China and the Indian subcontinent. Due to its ornamental value, it has been introduced to other regions outside its native range.
distribution_introduced_art_desc: Abutilon macranthum was mainly introduced to New Zealand. It was brought there as an ornamental plant due to its attractive foliage and flowers.
